doc.title: fastDNAml

description.text: Construction of phylogenetic trees of DNA sequences using maximum likelihood

doc.reference: Olsen, G. J., Matsuda, H., Hagstrom, R., and Overbeek, R. 1994. fastDNAml: A tool for construction of phylogenetic trees of DNA sequences using maximum likelihood. Comput. Appl. Biosci. 10: 41-48.
Felsenstein, J. 1981. Evolutionary trees from DNA sequences: A maximum likelihood approach. J. Mol. Evol. 17: 368-376.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The input to fastDNAml is similar to that used by DNAML (and the other PHYLIP programs). At least 3 sequences are required.

xhtml:div.label: Use empirical base frequencies derived from the sequence data ? Yes No

fieldset.legend: User bases frequencies (instead of empirical frequencies)

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: A frequency

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: C frequency

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: G frequency

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: T frequency

Transition/transversion ratio?
This option can be used before a global or treefile option with auxiliary data.

Randomize input order of sequences (jumble)?
Yes No
Note that fastDNAml explores a very small number of alternative tree topologies relative to a typical parsimony program. There is a very real chance that the search procedure will not find the tree topology with the highest likelihood. Altering the order of taxon addition and comparing the trees found is a fairly efficient method for testing convergence. Typically, it would be nice to find the same best tree at least twice (if not three times), as opposed to simply performing some fixed number of jumbles and hoping that at least one of them will be the optimum.

Global rearrangements?
Yes No
The G (global) option has been generalized to permit crossing any number of branches during tree rearrangements. In addition, it is possible to modify the extent of rearrangement explored during the sequential addition phase of tree building.
The G U (global and user tree) option combination instructs the program to find the best of the user trees, and then look for rearrangements that are better still.
If a rearrangement distance is specified, the input must contain a transition option.
The Global option can be used to force branch swapping on user trees, (combination of Global and User Tree(s) options).
Number of branches to cross in rearrangements of the completed tree
Number of branches to cross in testing rearrangements during the sequential addition phase of tree inference

Decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (quickadd)?
Yes No
This option greatly decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (but does not change the time required to subsequently test rearrangements). The overall time savings seems to be about 30%, based on a very limited number of test cases. Its downside, if any, is unknown. This will probably become default program behavior in the near future.
If the analysis is run with a global option of 'G 0 0', so that no rearrangements are permitted, the tree is build very approximately, but very quickly. This may be of greatest interest if the question is, 'Where does this one new sequence fit into this known tree?' The known tree is provided with the restart option, below.
PHYLIP DNAML does not include anything comparable to the quickadd option.
Use the specified sequence number as outgroup

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This options allows you to enter your own trees and instructs the program to evaluate them.
The trees must be in Newick format, and terminated with a semicolon. (The program also accepts a pseudo_newick format, which is a valid prolog fact.)

The tree reader in this program is more powerful than that in PHYLIP 3.3. In particular, material enclosed in square brackets, [ like this ], is ignored as comments; taxa names can be wrapped in single quotation marks to support the inclusion of characters that would otherwise end the name (i.e., '(', ')', ':', ';', '[', ']', ',' and ' '); names of internal nodes are properly ignored; and exponential notation (such as 1.0E-6) for branch lengths is supported.

xhtml:div.label:
User trees to be read with branch lengths?
Yes No
Causes user trees to be read with branch lengths (and it is an error to omit any of them). Without the L option, branch lengths in user trees are not required, and are ignored if present.

Generates a re-sample of the input data (bootstrap)?
Yes No
Tree files will be summarized in one '.tree' file as well as output files in one '.out' file
Number of different bootstrap samples

Random number seed for first bootstrap?
Warning: For a given random number seed, the sample will always be the same.
Maximum attempts at replicating inferred tree (max jumble)
Output File
Save tree in treefile Yes No
Print the input alignment at start of run (printdata) Yes No

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The data must have the format specified for PHYLIP dnaml 3.3. The first line must be the letter C, followed by the number of categories (a number in the range 1 through 35), and then a blank-separated list of the rates for each category. (The list can take more than one line; the program reads until it finds the specified number of rate values.) The next line should be the word Categories followed by one rate category character per sequence position. The categories 1 - 35 are represented by the series 1, 2, 3, ..., 8, 9, A, B, C, ..., Y, Z. These latter data can be on one or more lines. For example:
Category 'numbers' are ordered: 1, 2, 3, ..., 9, A, B, ..., Y, Z. Category zero (undefined rate) is permitted at sites with a zero in a user-supplied weighting mask.
example:
In case of bootstrap, only positions that have nonzero weights are used in computing the bootstrap sample.
The input to fastDNAml is similar to that used by DNAML (and the other PHYLIP programs). At least 3 sequences are required.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: User bases frequencies (instead of empirical frequencies)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option can be used before a global or treefile option with auxiliary data.

Note that fastDNAml explores a very small number of alternative tree topologies relative to a typical parsimony program. There is a very real chance that the search procedure will not find the tree topology with the highest likelihood. Altering the order of taxon addition and comparing the trees found is a fairly efficient method for testing convergence. Typically, it would be nice to find the same best tree at least twice (if not three times), as opposed to simply performing some fixed number of jumbles and hoping that at least one of them will be the optimum.

The G (global) option has been generalized to permit crossing any number of branches during tree rearrangements. In addition, it is possible to modify the extent of rearrangement explored during the sequential addition phase of tree building.
The G U (global and user tree) option combination instructs the program to find the best of the user trees, and then look for rearrangements that are better still.
If a rearrangement distance is specified, the input must contain a transition option.
The Global option can be used to force branch swapping on user trees, (combination of Global and User Tree(s) options).

This option greatly decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (but does not change the time required to subsequently test rearrangements). The overall time savings seems to be about 30%, based on a very limited number of test cases. Its downside, if any, is unknown. This will probably become default program behavior in the near future.

If the analysis is run with a global option of 'G 0 0', so that no rearrangements are permitted, the tree is build very approximately, but very quickly. This may be of greatest interest if the question is, 'Where does this one new sequence fit into this known tree?' The known tree is provided with the restart option, below.
PHYLIP DNAML does not include anything comparable to the quickadd option.
The trees must be in Newick format, and terminated with a semicolon. (The program also accepts a pseudo_newick format, which is a valid prolog fact.)

The tree reader in this program is more powerful than that in PHYLIP 3.3. In particular, material enclosed in square brackets, [ like this ], is ignored as comments; taxa names can be wrapped in single quotation marks to support the inclusion of characters that would otherwise end the name (i.e., '(', ')', ':', ';', '[', ']', ',' and ' '); names of internal nodes are properly ignored; and exponential notation (such as 1.0E-6) for branch lengths is supported.
Causes user trees to be read with branch lengths (and it is an error to omit any of them). Without the L option, branch lengths in user trees are not required, and are ignored if present.
Tree files will be summarized in one '.tree' file as well as output files in one '.out' file
Warning: For a given random number seed, the sample will always be the same.

The data must have the format specified for PHYLIP dnaml 3.3. The first line must be the letter C, followed by the number of categories (a number in the range 1 through 35), and then a blank-separated list of the rates for each category. (The list can take more than one line; the program reads until it finds the specified number of rate values.) The next line should be the word Categories followed by one rate category character per sequence position. The categories 1 - 35 are represented by the series 1, 2, 3, ..., 8, 9, A, B, C, ..., Y, Z. These latter data can be on one or more lines. For example:
Category 'numbers' are ordered: 1, 2, 3, ..., 9, A, B, ..., Y, Z. Category zero (undefined rate) is permitted at sites with a zero in a user-supplied weighting mask.

In case of bootstrap, only positions that have nonzero weights are used in computing the bootstrap sample.

parameter.name: frequencies
parameter.prompt: Use empirical base frequencies derived from the sequence data ?

format.code: ( "" ,"frequencies %s %s %s %s | " % (str(fA), str(fC), str(fG), str(fT)) )[ not ( value and fA is None and fC is None and fG is None and fT is None) ]

interface.label: Use empirical base frequencies derived from the sequence data ? Yes No

The G U (global and user tree) option combination instructs the program to find the best of the user trees, and then look for rearrangements that are better still.

parameter.name: quickadd
parameter.prompt: Decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (quickadd)

comment.text: This option greatly decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (but does not change the time required to subsequently test rearrangements). The overall time savings seems to be about 30%, based on a very limited number of test cases. Its downside, if any, is unknown. This will probably become default program behavior in the near future.

If the analysis is run with a global option of 'G 0 0', so that no rearrangements are permitted, the tree is build very approximately, but very quickly. This may be of greatest interest if the question is, 'Where does this one new sequence fit into this known tree?' The known tree is provided with the restart option, below.
PHYLIP DNAML does not include anything comparable to the quickadd option.

interface.label:
Decreases the time in initially placing a new sequence in the growing tree (quickadd)?
Yes No

comment.text: The trees must be in Newick format, and terminated with a semicolon. (The program also accepts a pseudo_newick format, which is a valid prolog fact.)

The tree reader in this program is more powerful than that in PHYLIP 3.3. In particular, material enclosed in square brackets, [ like this ], is ignored as comments; taxa names can be wrapped in single quotation marks to support the inclusion of characters that would otherwise end the name (i.e., '(', ')', ':', ';', '[', ']', ',' and ' '); names of internal nodes are properly ignored; and exponential notation (such as 1.0E-6) for branch lengths is supported.

parameter.name: bootstrap
parameter.prompt: Generates a re-sample of the input data (bootstrap)

comment.text: Tree files will be summarized in one '.tree' file as well as output files in one '.out' file

interface.label:
Generates a re-sample of the input data (bootstrap)?
Yes No
Tree files will be summarized in one '.tree' file as well as output files in one '.out' file

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tree files will be summarized in one '.tree' file as well as output files in one '.out' file

format.code: ( "" , " -boots " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

message.text: More than 1000 samples is not possible on this server

interface.label: Number of different bootstrap samples

parameter.name: bootstrap_seed
parameter.prompt: Random number seed for first bootstrap

comment.text: Warning: For a given random number seed, the sample will always be the same.

interface.label:
Random number seed for first bootstrap?
Warning: For a given random number seed, the sample will always be the same.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Warning: For a given random number seed, the sample will always be the same.

parameter.name: bootstrap_maxjumble
parameter.prompt: Maximum attempts at replicating inferred tree (max jumble)

format.code: ( "" , " -jumble " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Maximum attempts at replicating inferred tree (max jumble)
Output File

precond.code: not bootstrap and outfile is None
not bootstrap and outfile is not None

interface.label: Save tree in treefile Yes No

parameter.name: printdata
parameter.prompt: Print the input alignment at start of run (printdata)

interface.label: Print the input alignment at start of run (printdata) Yes No

comment.text: The data must have the format specified for PHYLIP dnaml 3.3. The first line must be the letter C, followed by the number of categories (a number in the range 1 through 35), and then a blank-separated list of the rates for each category. (The list can take more than one line; the program reads until it finds the specified number of rate values.) The next line should be the word Categories followed by one rate category character per sequence position. The categories 1 - 35 are represented by the series 1, 2, 3, ..., 8, 9, A, B, C, ..., Y, Z. These latter data can be on one or more lines. For example:
Category 'numbers' are ordered: 1, 2, 3, ..., 9, A, B, ..., Y, Z. Category zero (undefined rate) is permitted at sites with a zero in a user-supplied weighting mask.
